body:
except Chrome just landed shadow DOM in stable (not just canary/beta), and requires the /deep/ syntax to style things across the shadow boundary (based on the discussion I'm hearing from the Polymer guys, this is the official CSS syntax for deep styling).

Definitely giving that escaping solution a try though.

> I don't like the `/deep/`  syntax, 

Yeah, now waiting for the `/high/` combinator.

issue.title: error when parsing new /deep/ combinator for CSS Shadow DOM

body: Two more months now, as pointed out its in Chrome Stable, and used by Polymer, which got a good deal of focus at Google IO with their heavy push to Material Design.  They work in SASS https://groups.google.com/d/msg/polymer-dev/MMa1SyezpfI/ZEytHHIJ6Z0J

issue.title: Parent Selectors should have targets
issue.body:
When creating a Parent Selector rule, everything before the `&` gets prepended to the outermost scope.  

The feature could be greatly improved by allowing for "parent targeting", where you could apply the parent selector to a specific parent (in the case where you have deeply nested selectors).

The syntax for this feature is probably the biggest hindrance, so I would love to start a discussion on the possibilities.

body: it shouldn't be too hard to add as a combinator, I'll keep this on my radar for when I have time

I'm doing now. I found we support

```
.a ^ .b,
.a ^^ .b {
}
```

was that an old syntax or is that nothing to do with shadow dom?
Yes, `^^` is the old syntax and we don't need to support it anymore (and `^` too if I'm not mistaken).

issue.title: /deep/ selector is lost when is followed by spaces
use variables for combinators
Error: "no writecb in Transform class"
Less throws an error with the ">>>" combinator
issue.body:
Eg, 

```
ParseError: Unrecognised input in path\to\less\main.less on line 25, column 7:
24
25 html >>> .materialblue {
26
```

However, this is valid.

See:
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components/Shadow_DOM
- https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=446051
- https://w3c.github.io/webcomponents/spec/shadow/#composed-trees
- http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-scoping/#deep-combinator

This should be correctly passed through.
